qas.question: In what film was Arsenal FC shown?
What Arsenal manager had a speaking part in the 1939 film?
What book by Nick Hornby has twice been adapted for film?
In what decade did film and literature help revive football in Britain?
What was the name of the 1997 movie about Arsenal?
What was the name of the 2005 movie about the Boston Red Sox?
Who was the lead actor in Arsenal Stadium Mystery?
What player is poisoned during the Arsenal Stadium Mystery movie?
What stadium do the Boston Red Sox play in?

context: As one of the most successful teams in the country, Arsenal have often featured when football is depicted in the arts in Britain. They formed the backdrop to one of the earliest football-related films, <a0_0>The <b9_0>Arsenal Stadium<b9_0/> Mystery<a0_0/> (1939). The film centres on a friendly match between Arsenal and an amateur side, one of whose players is poisoned while playing. Many Arsenal players appeared as themselves and manager <a1_0>George Allison<a1_0/> was given a speaking part. More recently, the book <a2_0><b5_0><b6_0>Fever Pitch<b6_0/><b5_0/><a2_0/> by <b7_0><b8_0>Nick Hornby<b8_0/><b7_0/> was an autobiographical account of Hornby's life and relationship with football and Arsenal in particular. Published in <a3_0>1992<a3_0/>, it formed part of the revival and rehabilitation of football in British society during the <a4_0>1990s<a4_0/>. The book was twice adapted for the cinema – the 1997 British film focuses on Arsenal's 1988–89 title win, and a 2005 American version features a fan of baseball's Boston Red Sox.
